Description: Scarab carved from chalky white stone, likely steatite; underside incised with the name of Menkheperra inscribed in an horizontal oval, surmounting a red crown and a Hes vase; glaze worn; broken.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Scarab Factory (according to museum register)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The name of Menkheperra appears on a wide range of scarabs. It does not necessarily refer to the prenomen of Thutmosis III and it is used here to write the name of the god Amun-Ra. In addition to this specimen from Naukratis, Jaeger quoted several examples from various Mediterranean sites where such scarabs were discovered (Jaeger 1982, 56, § 196). A similar scarab was found in Motya in Sicily (Gorton 1996, type VI, 19-20, no. 14). Another close parallel, but made of glazed composition and with a winged sun on the top register, was discovered in Italy, in a context dated around 700 BC (Hölbl 1979, 9, pl. 67/2, no. 28). Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Hölbl, G. 1979, Beziehungen der ägyptischen Kultur zu Altitalien (EPRO 62/II), Leiden. Jaeger, B. 1982. Essai de classification et datation des scarabées Menkhéperrê. Fribourg.
Bibliographic references: Jaeger 1982 / Essai de classification et datation des scarabées Menkhéperrê (56, § 196, ill. 71)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OA.54) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
